title: Four typefaces on Tarkovsky soundtrack CD covers
content:
Hello  
I'm trying to find the four typefaces used on this series of Tarkovsky soundtrack CDs released by Toei Music Publishing (Japan) in the mid-1990s.

• The italic used for the film titles – "Zerkalo" and "Stalker".  
• The bold condensed grotesk used for "Andrey Tarkovsky" (possibly Akzidenz Bold Condensed?)  
• The glittery number "4"  
• The typewriter font used for the glittery Cyrillic version of "Tarkovsky"

I have a couple more images from other CDs in this series if anybody needs extra letters or numbers to work with, but they are a bit more blurry than this one.

I know it's a lot to ask, so thanks in advance.

Andrew

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20130412135357im_/http:/typophile.com/files/iz_69_3_orig_3767.jpg)
author: An Accident

comments.content:
To start, the 4 is Bodoni, or some clone...

Zerkalo-Stalker looks like a faux-italic (ultra-slanty), squooshed garamond (hook at the end of the leg of lowercase k)

It's not AG bold condensed (descender on y is too stubby, arm on k doesn't look right). Perhaps Helvetica Black Condensed?  
 [http://www.linotype.com/12573/helveticablackcondensed-font.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20130412135357/http:/www.linotype.com/12573/helveticablackcondensed-font.html "http://www.linotype.com/12573/helveticablackcondensed-font.html")

Thanks for the help.  
It hadn't occurred to me that it might be Helvetica. I'm obviously a bit slow this morning.

I had a feeling that extra slanting and a bit of squooshing may have taken place, because Garamond and Plantin italics  
were looking pretty 'upright' in comparison.

Andrew

James, I don't think it's Helvetica Compressed. That variance has a different lowercase r. The ear points downward. I think black condensed looks closer.

I'm tapped out on the cyrillic.

You are right, but condensed looks wide. Maybe [CG Triumvirate Inserat](http://web.archive.org/web/20130412135357/http:/www.identifont.com/show?3ZJ) or [Helvetica Inserat](http://web.archive.org/web/20130412135357/http:/www.identifont.com/show?MU).

<cite>I’m tapped out on the cyrillic.</cite>

X2 and I feel like I've seen it very recently.
It's not quite a match, but [FF Elementa](http://web.archive.org/web/20130412135357/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/fontfont/ff_elementa_cyrillic/) is close.

Thanks for all your efforts.

FF Elementa is interesting, I hadn't seen it before.

I'll keep looking for the typewriter font and I'll do some squooshing experiments with Garamond (shudder).
The K is interesting. You have a hint of ball serifs and a particular flavor that is not common in typewriter fonts.
